0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-polling-analysis-idUSKCN12S13U	Clinton holds lead
column2: but pollsters say their job is harder	"

column1: By Scott Malone
| BOSTON
BOSTON Many opinion polls show Democrat Hillary Clinton leading Republican Donald Trump in a tight race for the Nov. 8 U.S. presidential election
column2: but any one of four factors may make the outcome harder to predict.Among the challenges for pollsters: The historic unpopularity of both candidates
column3: the potential Election Day voter response to the polls themselves
column4: the growing abandonment of landlines for cellphones
column5: and the rise of online polling.Some high-profile stumbles worldwide - including opinion polls that missed Colombia's Oct. 2 rejection of a peace deal - underscore how technological
column6: social and cultural shifts have made polling more difficult than ever.An average of polls compiled by RealClearPolitics.com shows former Secretary of State Clinton beating Trump
column8: by 5.4 percentage points. Highlighting the difficulties
column9: the range varies from plus-13 for Clinton to a straight tie.Trump has said the election is rigged against him and this week
column11: he accused media organizations of tilting the polls deliberately
column12: but he has yet to offer any widely accepted evidence to back up these claims.Voter turnout in the last few presidential elections has been about 60 percent. But given both candidates' low overall popularity
column13: turnout this year may fall to as low as 52 percent
column15: a professor emeritus of political science at New Jersey's Rutgers University and a former president of the American Association for Public Opinion Research. That makes it hard to guess who might stay home.""It's always been difficult to simulate a likely electorate and I think that's harder to do in 2016

column1: A second pitfall is the effect of the polling itself on voters. Sociologists believe polls can weaken projected winners by making their supporters more confident of the outcome and
column2: therefore
column3: less likely to vote. The percentage of Trump supporters who expect him to win has dropped to 49 percent in a Reuters/Ipsos poll conducted from Oct. 20-24
column4: down from 74 percent from Sept. 16-20. Clinton supporters' confidence rose at the same time.

column1: If that leads to a higher turnout of Trump supporters than of Clinton supporters
column2: it might affect the election outcome.Pollsters caution
column3: however
column4: that the effect of polls on the electorate can only go so far.    ""If it were showing Clinton up by 2 points
column5: then it's certainly possible that it would be within the margin of error that Trump might win
column6: said Douglas Schwartz
column7: director of the Quinnipiac University Poll.""But if you're finding that all of these high-quality polls are showing Clinton consistently ahead
column8: then I think you can trust them

column1: One of the biggest factors in polling today is the prevalence of cellphones. About half of Americans have only a cellphone and no landline
column2: according to Federal Communications Commission data
column3: more than double the number who were wireless-only in 2010. This makes it harder and more expensive for pollsters to gather a truly random sample of opinions because U.S. law prohibits computerized auto-dialing (also known as robocalls) to cellphones and there is no central directory for cellphones. Polling cellphones can costs 30 to 50 percent more than polling land lines due to requirements that the numbers be dialed manually
column4: according to Pew Research Center estimates. This has led polling outfits to generally rely on lower sample sizes to come up with results.Calls to cellphones are also more easily screened by their users
column5: and as a result pollsters say they connect with just 10 percent of people they try to contact
column6: down from 80 percent a few decades ago. But Courtney Kennedy
column7: director of survey research at Pew said
column9: the quality is better."" Many respondents on cellphones are young and racially diverse

column1: ONLINE SURVEYS A FACTOR
Others
column2: such as Reuters/Ipsos
column3: conduct surveys online. This allows them to reach large numbers of people at lower cost. But because participants are volunteers in many cases
column4: rather than selected at random
column5: segments of the electorate may be left out.    The lower or skewed response in both cellphone and online polls can pose a challenge with pollsters having to adjust results to match the real world. To accomplish this
column6: they weight more heavily the opinions of types of voters under-represented in their surveys.Pollsters use population statistics
column7: experience and intuition to do this. For instance
column8: if the proportion of men who respond to a survey is lower than their proportion of the overall population
column9: the pollster will adjust the finding to try to even that out.""Then you've built in an assumption that the males that didn't respond are like the males that responded. And that's an unknowable fact
column12: a social statistician and author of seven books on polling who served as director of the U.S. Census Bureau from 2009 through 2012.But such modeling can work well in some cases.A study by Columbia University statisticians
column13: published in 2014 in the International Journal of Forecasting
column14: showed that a poll of users of Microsoft Corp's Xbox gaming system could be used to accurately predict the election's outcome.The gamers were far younger
column15: whiter and more male than the U.S. electorate and predicted a sweeping victory for Republican Mitt Romney in 2012. But when the results were weighted according to voters who turned out in 2008
column16: they predicted President Barack Obama's 2012 re-election.Getting the weightings right this time could be a tougher job because Trump has attracted many supporters who historically have voted erratically
column17: or not at all.""We can't apply 2008 and 2012 models to 2016
column19: director of the Eagleton Center for Public Interest Polling at Rutgers University.    (Reporting by Scott Malone; Additional reporting by Steve Holland in Boynton Beach
column21: and Maurice Tamman in New York; Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Howard Goller)"	['Romney'

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN12R2T6	Trump attacks Clinton on trade
column2: says he should be handed victory	"

column1: By Steve Holland and Jeff Mason
TOLEDO
column2: Ohio; WINSTON SALEM
column3: N.C. U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump criticized Democrat Hillary Clinton on Thursday over her trade policies
column4: saying she would handle trade deals so badly that the country should ""just cancel the election"" and name him the victor. Speaking to supporters in Toledo
column5: Ohio
column6: Trump said the North American Free Trade Agreement signed by Clinton's husband
column8: had led to the outsourcing of thousands of Ohio jobs to Mexico
column9: a practice he vowed to stop if elected president on Nov. 8.""We should just cancel the election and just give it to Trump
column10: right?"" he said. ""What are we even having it for? Her policies are so bad.""Trump said he believed Clinton would seek passage of the 12-nation Trans Pacific Partnership
column11: President Barack Obama's signature Asian trade deal
column12: which she now opposes.Trump's remarks came as the New York businessman tries to steady rocky poll numbers amid a series of controversies and self-inflicted wounds. He has struggled to handle the fallout from the release of a 2005 ""Access Hollywood"" video that showed the then-reality TV star talking on an open microphone about groping women and trying to seduce a married woman. The video was taped only months after Trump married his third wife
column13: Melania.Trump said on Thursday it was ""certainly illegal"" for NBC to release the tape and he left open the option of seeking legal action against the network after the election.Since the video's release
column14: a series of women have accused Trump of groping them or kissing them without their consent. Trump has called the allegations ""absolutely false.""The latest RealClearPolitics poll average showed Clinton with a nearly 6-point national lead over Trump
column15: fueled by declining support among women for his candidacy.Trump
column17: has blamed his sagging poll numbers on a rigged election
column18: and said the media had fixed the opinion polls in order to inflate Clinton's numbers.

column1: Numerous studies have shown that voter fraud in U.S. elections is very rare
column2: and a number of prominent Republicans have denounced Trump's claim that the system is unsound.While Trump campaigned in  Ohio
column3: a plane carrying his running mate
column4: Indiana Governor Mike Pence
column5: skidded off the runway after landing at New York City's LaGuardia Airport on Thursday night. There were no injuries
column6: the Pence campaign said.STUMPING WITH FIRST LADY

column1: Clinton on Thursday made her first joint campaign appearance with one of her most powerful supporters
column2: first lady Michelle Obama
column3: at a North Carolina rally to urge young people and women to vote.Clinton
column4: a former first lady who lost the 2008 Democratic nomination to then-U.S. Senator Barack Obama before becoming his secretary of state
column5: praised Michelle Obama for standing up for the rights of girls and women worldwide
column6: drawing a sharp contrast with her Republican rival.

column1: I wish I didn't have to say this. ... But indeed
column2: dignity and respect for women and girls is also on the ballot in this election
column3: Clinton told a crowd of about 11
column4: 000. ""And I want to thank our first lady for her eloquent
column5: powerful defense of that basic value.""Michelle Obama's stinging denunciation of Trump after a leaked 2005 video showed him making lewd remarks and bragging about groping women was seen by many as one of the campaign's most striking condemnations of the New York businessman.Without naming Trump
column6: Obama took him to task again in North Carolina
column7: asking the crowd which candidate they wanted to represent their daughters from the White House.""We want a president who takes this job seriously
column8: and has the temperament and maturity to do it well. Someone who is steady. Someone who we can trust with the nuclear codes
column9: Obama said. ""I would not be here lying to you: I believe with all of my heart that Hillary Clinton will be that president

column1: Although Michelle Obama was critical of Clinton during the hard-fought 2008 Democratic nominating race
column2: any trace of bitterness appeared long behind them. The two women showed an easy rapport. They embraced and smiled. Obama called Clinton ""my girl"" and made a point of telling the crowd they were tight.""If people wonder: Yes
column3: Hillary Clinton is my friend
column4: she said.Clinton promised to take good care of Obama's White House vegetable garden if she won and wistfully praised the athletic first lady's dancing skills. ""One could only hope
column5: Clinton said.She also lauded Obama's work for children and military families and in what was perhaps a nod to African-Americans she hopes will vote for her in the state
column6: said Obama had faced challenges she had not as a presidential spouse.""Let's be real. As our first African-American first lady
column7: she's faced pressures I never did
column8: and she's handled them with pure grace
column9: Clinton said to applause.Although a sometimes reluctant campaigner
column10: the first lady has thrown herself into the race
column11: and the Clinton campaign has deployed her strategically to increase support among young people and blacks
column12: with whom she is especially popular. (Writing by Alana Wise and John Whitesides; Editing by Peter Cooney)"	['Pence'

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-brazil-corruption-trump-idUSKCN12S05D	Brazil prosecutor says Trump franchise may have benefited from corruption	"
By Anthony Boadle
| BRASILIA

BRASILIA A Brazilian prosecutor investigating potentially corrupt investments made by state pension funds said the real estate company run by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump appears to have benefited ""suspiciously"" from a massive redevelopment of Rio de Janeiro's port ahead of the Olympics.The development
column2: known as Porto Maravilha
column3: or Marvelous Port in Portuguese
column4: cost 8 billion reais ($2.5 billion) and developed run-down docklands into a plaza
column5: museums
column6: corporate and residential real estate. As part of the project
column7: five 38-story buildings were meant to be erected under the Trump brand. Public prosecutor Alselmo Lopes said in a court filing made public on Thursday that he is investigating the Porto Maravilha deal
column8: in which the national employee severance fund FGTS
column9: managed by state-bank Caixa Economica Federal [CEF.UL]
column10: paid up-front for building rights which it then sold on.     The structuring of the Porto Maravilha deal ""favored
column14: Lopes said. The prosecutor gave no further details and was not immediately reachable for comment. His spokeswoman
column16: said Lopes would not explain the basis for his suspicions until next week.

column1: None of the five people Lopes sought to charge in the court filing for siphoning off 8 billion reais from the Caixa's pension fund were related to the Trump Organization.  The Trump Organization
column2: which sold naming rights for the Rio towers but did not provide any funding for the project
column3: did not immediately respond to requests for comment. A senior executive involved in the Trump Towers Rio dismissed the prosecutor's charge as baseless.

column1: Any allegations that the Porto Maravilha Investment Fund of Caixa Economica Federal has favored in a suspicious way the Trump Organization economic group are completely unfounded
column2: the executive
column3: who asked not to be named
column4: said by email. Not long after plans for the towers were first announced
column5: Donald Trump tweeted in January 2013: ""The Trump Organization is going revolutionize Rio de Janeiro's downtown port area with Trump Towers. Construction begins soon!""

column1: Two of the five Trump Towers were supposed to be ready by the Olympics
column2: but ground has yet to be broken. Developers say the project is still going ahead and has not been scrapped.Trump Towers Rio on its website claims it is the first project in Brazil to bear the name of the U.S. real estate magnate and the largest urban office development in the BRICS group of leading emerging market countries. (Additional reporting by Stephen Eisenhammer; Editing by Daniel Flynn and Bill Rigby)"	['Trump']	[]

column3: Ohio

column6: then turned to the side to blow out a puff of air from his mouth. ""And he'd fall over.""Trump is 70 years old. Biden is 73. Both have been known to delve into hyperbole.

By Amy Tennery
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK With the U.S. election just days away
column2: Americans can expect to see an occasional ""nasty woman"" and ""basket of deplorables"" knocking on doors this Halloween alongside the usual parade of goblins

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-obamacare-idUSKCN12R2UI	Obama rallies Obamacare troops at 'critical time' for program	"
By Roberta Rampton
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON President Barack Obama on Thursday urged more than 25
column2: 000 volunteers and advocates who dialed in to a White House conference call to pull out the stops to boost the number of people signing up for Obamacare health insurance plans.Obama warned it will be challenging to overcome the skepticism about the plans given an onslaught of headlines about surging premium prices
column3: but he said the stakes are high.""I think we're at a critical time where we have to show that this program works for people
column4: if they just see what their options are
column5: he told the volunteers
column6: who work in their communities to encourage and assist enrollment.Americans who do not receive health insurance through their employer or through Medicare or Medicaid programs shop online for subsidized insurance plans starting Nov. 1 until the end of January.The average premium for benchmark 2017 plans sold on healthcare.gov rose 25 percent compared with 2016.

column1: Obama said tax credits will help more than seven in 10 shoppers get a plan for less than $75 per month
column2: but said many may not bother looking because they have heard about spiking costs.""We're going to have to clear the bugs off the windshield so people can see the road ahead
column3: and that's where you guys come in
column4: Obama said.The law has been fought by Republicans in Congress
column5: who said it creates unwarranted government intervention in personal healthcare and private industry.

column1: Several big insurers
column2: including UnitedHealth Group Inc (UNH.N)
column3: Aetna Inc (AET.N) and Humana Inc (HUM.N)
column4: are pulling out of the online marketplaces selling the subsidized plans
column5: citing bigger-than-expected financial losses.Aetna Chief Executive Mark Bertolini said on Thursday that the earliest his company may return to the marketplaces would be 2019.

column1: Obama said more young and healthy people need to sign up for plans. That would offset insurers' costs of covering members with serious illnesses.Obama has said there are a series of improvements that could be made to his signature domestic policy achievement - the 2010 Affordable Care Act - if Congress and the next president
column2: who will take office on Jan. 20
column3: can work together.""Part of what we can do this time is to overcome the skeptics
column4: to prove people wrong
column5: and to provide momentum so that when the next administration comes in
column6: they are starting from a position of strength
column7: Obama told the conference call. (Reporting by Roberta Rampton; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Obama']	['healthcare']

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-justice-obama-idUSKCN12R2OA	Obama shortens prison sentences for 98 convicts: White House	"
WASHINGTON U.S. President Barack Obama shortened the prison sentences for 98 convicts serving time for drug-related offenses in his latest round of commutations
column2: including for 42 people serving life sentences
column3: the White House said on Thursday.Obama has granted 688 commutations this year
column4: for a total so far of 872 during his presidency
column5: which ends on Jan. 20.""These are individuals - many of whom made mistakes at a young age - who have diligently worked to rehabilitate themselves while incarcerated
column6: White House Counsel Neil Eggleston said in a statement.

column1: The commutations are part of Obama's push to reform the criminal justice system to reduce the number of people serving long sentences for non-violent drug offenses.
Obama and a bipartisan group of lawmakers in the U.S. Congress had tried to work on legislation to reduce mandatory minimum sentences
column2: but those efforts stalled ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election.

column1: (Reporting by Roberta Rampton; Editing by James Dalgleish)"	['Obama']	[]
7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-congress-idUSKCN12R2QN	U.S. lawmakers raise privacy concerns over new hacking rules	"
By Dustin Volz
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON A bipartisan group of lawmakers in the U.S. Congress on Thursday asked the Justice Department to clarify how a looming rule change to the government's hacking powers could impact privacy rights of innocent Americans.The change
column2: due to take place on December 1
column3: would let judges issue search warrants for remote access to computers located in any jurisdiction
column4: potentially including foreign countries. Magistrate judges can normally only order searches within the jurisdiction of their court
column5: which is typically limited to a few counties.""We are concerned about the full scope of the new authority that would be provided to the Department of Justice
column6: 23 senators and representatives wrote to Attorney General Loretta Lynch.The Supreme Court in April approved amendments to Rule 41 of the federal rules of criminal procedure that would allow judges to issue warrants in cases when a suspect uses anonymizing technology to conceal the location of his or her computer or for an investigation into a network of hacked or infected computers

column1: Those amendments will take effect on December 1 of this year unless Congress passes legislation that would reject
column2: amend or postpone the changes. Some lawmakers
column3: led by Democratic Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon
column4: have introduced legislation that would halt the changes
column5: but it has yet to gain much traction.In their letter
column6: the lawmakers asked how the government would prevent under the expanded rule so-called ""forum shopping
column7: where prosecutors seek warrants in districts considered more favorable to law enforcement.

column1: They also asked how the Justice Department intends to notify users when electronic devices have been searched and whether law enforcement has the authority to disable malicious software on a protected device
column2: including those belonging to innocent Americans
column3: among other questions. The Justice Department has worked on Rule 41 changes for years
column4: arguing they are procedural in nature and necessary to keep pace with criminal threats posed by evolving technology.

column1: Civil liberties groups and some technology companies
column2: including Alphabet Inc's Google
column3: have said the changes could allow for searches that run afoul of privacy rights.The Justice Department is reviewing the lawmakers' letter
column4: which asked for a response within two weeks
column5: spokesman Peter Carr said. (Reporting by Dustin Volz; Editing by Mary Milliken)"	['Wyden'
column6: 'Lynch']	[]

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-putin-idUSKCN12R1W6	Putin says U.S. 'hysteria' over Russia is election ploy	"
By Gleb Stolyarov
| KRASNAYA POLYANA
column2: Russia

column1: KRASNAYA POLYANA
column2: Russia President Vladimir Putin on Thursday accused American politicians of whipping up hysteria about a mythical Russian threat as a ploy to distract voters from their own failings in the run-up to the U.S. presidential election.Putin
column3: addressing an audience of foreign policy experts gathered in southern Russia
column4: repeatedly lashed out at the Obama administration
column5: saying it did not keep its word on Syria
column6: did not honour deals
column7: and had falsely accused Moscow of all manner of sins.    The U.S. government has formally accused Russia of a campaign of cyber attacks against Democratic Party organisations
column8: while Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton has accused Republican rival Donald Trump of being a Putin ""puppet"".Putin said he found it hard to believe that anyone seriously thought Moscow was capable of influencing the Nov. 8 election.""Hysteria has been whipped up
column9: said Putin. He said that was a ruse to cover up for the fact that the U.S. political elite had nothing to say about serious issues such as the country's national debt or gun control.

column1: U.S. IS ""GREAT POWER""
It's much simpler to distract people with so-called Russian hackers
column2: spies
column3: and agents of influence. Does anyone really think that Russia could influence the American people's choice in any way? Is America a banana republic or what? America is a great power.""In Washington
column4: White House spokesman Josh Earnest dismissed Putin's remarks as predictable and said the United States stood by its hacking allegations.

column1: There's nothing that President Putin had to say today that I find particularly surprising or that in any way undermines the president's confidence in the analysis that's been released by the Department of Homeland Security and the intelligence community
column2: said Earnest.Russian state TV and some of his past comments have suggested the Russian leader favours Trump
column3: but Putin said he did not back any candidate in the U.S. election and was ready to work with any new U.S. president and to discuss any issue. Asked about Trump
column4: whom he once described as ""very talented
column5: Putin said the Republican candidate was deliberately adopting a showy style because he wanted to get his message across and that he represented ordinary voters fed up with the U.S. political elite.""He has chosen a method to get through to voters' hearts
column6: said Putin. ""He behaves extravagantly of course
column8: but I think there's a reason for this.""

column1: Putin dismissed suggestions by some politicians in the West that Russia is poised to attack another country or intervene elsewhere in the Middle East apart from Syria.   Such talk was designed to exaggerate the threat that Russia posed
column2: he said
column3: in order for certain countries to secure higher military spending and talk up their own importance.He said Russia was not planning to attack anyone.But he made clear Russia was in Syria for the long haul and intended to clear the city of Aleppo of what he called ""a nest of terrorists""
column4: while trying to minimise civilian casualties. (Additional reporting by Vladimir Soldatkin and Maria Tsvetkova in Moscow and Doina Chiacu in Washington; Writing by Andrew Osborn; Editing by Andrew Roche)"	['Clinton'
column5: 'Trump'
